stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the overworld, focusing on designing the layout for Part 3 (beach area) and solving a major technical challenge: creating a dynamic, localized fog effect for the ghost ship entrance. He also discussed his engine overhaul, design philosophies, and his other commissioned projects.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has rewritten nearly the entire Mario 64 engine, including rendering, animations (using quaternions), camera, collision, and parts of the OS, effectively creating a custom engine for the game.
development_findings.quote: Well, what you probably don't realize is that like almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

development_findings.summary: The overworld features non-linear design, such as a ghost ship level that is visible early but only accessible after activating a lighthouse in a later part of the game.
development_findings.quote: You do something later in the game to unlock something early in the game, that's cool as fuck.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream implementing a complex, localized fog effect for the ghost ship, combining distance-based fading, camera angle detection, and custom math to overcome N64 hardware limitations.
Kaze employs an iterative development process, working on multiple areas concurrently rather than perfecting one at a time, to allow for holistic adjustments as the overworld takes shape.
development_findings.quote: Because when we work on the other areas we will likely have to adjust this one again so if we do that we waste a shit ton of [time].

development_findings.summary: To avoid using simple cliffs as level boundaries, Kaze is designing natural barriers like giant bananas and forests to fit the game's Yoshi's Island theme.
Kaze replaced the original skybox system with one that uses custom-made 3D models for backgrounds.
development_findings.quote: I entirely ripped out the Mario 64 skybox system because it's hideous.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering using Python as a high-level scripting language, which would be interpreted at runtime to potentially improve performance by reducing data throughput.

context_findings.summary: Kaze muses on aging and cognition, theorizing his brain has become highly optimized for specific tasks like game design at the expense of other skills like solving math problems.
context_findings.quote: Sometimes I feel like I'm getting older and my brain doesn't work like it used to anymore. And then I also think that maybe my neurons just got more optimized and less variable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze clarifies that while he does take on paid commissions for other ROM hacks (like 'Drug Boss Mario'), 'Return to Yoshi's Island' is purely a passion project.
context_findings.quote: This one here is not any paid work at all, this is just me working because of passion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that for most applications, the choice of programming language is less important than the programmer's skill, unless performance is a critical factor.
context_findings.quote: I think only really bad programmers care about which programming language they use for most applications.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a theory that most games suffer from performance issues due to a single, poorly optimized element, reflecting his own focus on optimization.
context_findings.quote: I think 98% of games have at least one thing in them that costs like an unreasonable amount of performance and that's usually like the reason games lag.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is carefully selecting the first wave of beta testers for his other game, 'Drug Boss Mario', from long-time community members to minimize the risk of leaks.
Kaze expresses significant frustration with technical issues outside his control, such as NVIDIA Broadcast and OBS crashing during the stream.
The stream was conducted on Kaze's day off, and he ended it because he was feeling 'a little burned out,' indicating the project requires significant personal time.

biobak.summary: Kaze is awaiting a visual rework of the overworld by Biobak, indicating that Kaze creates the functional layout which Biobak then polishes aesthetically.
biobak.quote: I'd like to see the Biobak rework of the overworld.

biobak.summary: Kaze states that after Biobak's final rework of the overworld, they will be able to implement visual details like being able to see distant parts of the island from specific vantage points.

zeina.summary: Zeina (as Dainy Delphox in chat) provided a creative suggestion for the ghost ship's fog effect. After initial skepticism, Kaze understood and incorporated her idea.
zeina.quote: Oh, I see what you mean, Dainy Delphox. I see now, I see. I get your vision now.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears to have created a high-resolution render of the ghost ship, which Kaze used as a visual reference during the stream.
zeina.quote: Did you just make the ship for this render? Interesting.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Ghost Ship Fog
key_stories.summary: Kaze tackled the difficult technical challenge of creating a localized fog effect on the N64. After much trial, error, and debugging, he devised a custom solution combining distance and camera angle calculations to gate access to the ghost ship level.
key_stories.challenge: The N64's engine natively supports only global fog, but the design required a dynamic, localized fog effect around a ghost ship that would intensify as the player approached and looked at it.
key_stories.process: Kaze experimented with different mathematical formulas to control fog parameters. He debugged issues with inverted values and non-linear fog curves, eventually squaring a value to smooth the transition. He also planned to add supplementary visual elements like transparent planes and a 'decal Mario' to enhance the effect.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a multi-faceted solution using custom code that calculates fog intensity based on both player distance and camera angle relative to the ship, creating the desired localized effect.
key_stories.key_quote: Our entire issue, 100% of our issue is that we want the fork to be around the ship. That's entirely the problem.

key_stories.title: Building a Custom Engine on a Classic Foundation
key_stories.summary: Kaze revealed the immense scale of the project's technical foundation. To achieve his vision, he has systematically deconstructed and replaced the majority of the original Mario 64 engine, effectively building a new, more powerful engine for the 30-year-old hardware.
key_stories.challenge: The original Mario 64 engine is too limited for the ambitious scope of 'Return to Yoshi's Island', restricting creative and technical possibilities.
key_stories.process: Throughout the project's development, Kaze has systematically rewritten core components of the original game. He replaced the rendering pipeline, animation system, data structures, collision, physics steps, and even parts of the N64 operating system, leaving only a few key elements of vanilla Mario 64 intact.
key_stories.outcome: The game now runs on a heavily modified, bespoke engine that allows for modern features like quaternion animations, a custom camera, and advanced rendering, giving the team immense creative freedom.
key_stories.key_quote: Almost all of this engine here is my engine at this point. The only really thing that's still left from the vanilla 64 is Mario's physics.

open_questions.topic: The Custom Engine's Origin and Philosophy
open_questions.context: Kaze gave a detailed list of the many components of the Mario 64 engine he has completely replaced, stating it's almost entirely his own engine now.
questions: Was there a single moment or a specific limitation that made you decide, 'I have to rip this out and build my own'?
How do you decide what to keep from the original game versus what to rewrite? What is the value in keeping Mario's vanilla physics?
You're essentially building a new game engine for 30-year-old hardware. What's the most rewarding part of that challenge, and what's the most frustrating?

open_questions.context: Kaze and his wife, Zeina, had a creative back-and-forth about the fog effect. He initially seemed to dismiss her idea but later acknowledged her vision.
questions: Can you walk us through your creative process as a couple? How do you bounce ideas off each other, and how do you resolve creative disagreements when working on the same project?
Zeina, what was your original idea for the fog? How does it feel to contribute creative ideas during a live technical problem-solving session?

open_questions.context: Kaze explicitly stated that RTYI is a passion project, funded by his own time, unlike his other work which is often commissioned.
questions: How does your creative approach or your level of personal investment differ between a passion project like RTYI and your commissioned work?
What does it mean for you to work 'because of passion'? What is it about this specific project that drives you to invest so much personal time and effort?

open_questions.context: Kaze described a non-linear overworld puzzle where the player must activate a lighthouse late in the game to unlock the ghost ship area seen early in the game.
questions: What is your design philosophy behind creating these kinds of non-linear, long-term objectives in the overworld?
How do you balance guiding the player towards a solution like the lighthouse without making it too obvious and spoiling the sense of discovery?

open_questions.topic: Art and Level Design Collaboration Workflow
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned several times that he is building the functional 'blockout' of the overworld, which artist Biobak will then give a 'rework' or 'final pass'.
questions: What does the handoff process from you to Biobak look like? How do you communicate the intended mood, and how much creative freedom does he have in defining the final look?
Biobak, what is your process for taking Kaze's functional level geometry and transforming it into the final, polished art style of the game?
